awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Systematic Kinematic Survey of Young Milky Way Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will allow Dr. Kevin Covey to perform the INfrared Survey of Young Nebulous Clusters (IN-SYNC), which is a homogeneous, multi-epoch radial velocity survey of thousands of young stars in nearby clusters. IN-SYNC uses data from the Apachee Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE), as well as the Immersion Grating INfrared Spectrometer (IGRINS), in order to answer three questions:

1) How do star clusters form? 
2) What is the frequency of close binaries in young clusters?
3) What are the detailed stellar properties of pre-main sequence spectroscopic binaries?

The PI will also integrate his research and education programs by engaging citizen scientists through the Lowell Amateur Research Initiative (LARI). He will initially work with amateur astronomers to monitor variable young stars, which will provide valuable data for peer-reviewed publications. Dr. Covey will subsequently expand his program by directly connecting LARI participants to data from the robotic telescopes from Lowell Observatory.

Since star clusters are invaluable astrophysical laboratories, this work will provide unique tracers of the Milky Way's chemical evolution and star formation history, as well as enable stringent tests of stellar evolution models. Through the LARI initiative, this work will also result in increased public scientific literacy, as well as inform a new generation of citizen-science projects.

por.por_cntn:
The program CAREER: A Systematic Kinematic Survey of Young Milky Way Clusters used observations from the infrared APOGEE spectrograph, collected during the SDSS-III and SDSS-IV surveys, to investigate how young clusters, and the binary stars that reside within them, form and evolve over time.

This program contributed to 25 peer-reviewed scientific publications. Seven of these publications were led by undergraduate students at Western Washington University, while another was led by a masters student in the computer science department. 
Key research outcomes of this work include: 

 

  • the targeting and implementation of the APOGEE-2 Young Cluster Survey, producing a legacy dataset with 53,000 spectra of nearly 15,000 protostars in the Orion, Taurus, Perseus, Cygnus and Rosette molecular clouds, and moderately older clusters such as the Pleiades and Alpha Persei (Cottle et al. 2018; Beaton et al. 2022; Santana et al. 2022; Roman-Zuniga et al. (in prep));
  • decomposition of the structure, motions, and star formation history of the Orion star-forming complex, based on measurements from APOGEE spectra and positions, distances, and brightnesses measured by the Gaia satellite (Kounkel et al. 2018).  Among the many results in this work, which by late 2021 has been cited by more than 160 subsequent studies, perhaps the most striking is the clear signature of a supernova in the Lambda Orionis region dispersing its parental molecular cloud and triggering a new generation of star formation in the compressed rim of the expanding cloud. 
  • the identification, cataloguing, and age-dating of thousands of candidate clusters and extended linear structures within 1 kpc (Kounkel et al. 2019b) and 3 kpc (Kounkel et al. 2020) of the Sun. Follow-up work has since confirmed several of these new clusters and associations (e.g., Andrews et al. 2021; Curtis et al. 2021), and the presence of extended halo or tidal tails around previously known open clusters, supporting the fundamental conclusion that our Galaxy is much more highly structured than previously understood. 
  • a statistically robust, completeness-corrected measurement of the close binary fraction in nearby star forming regions & young clusters (Kounkel et al. 2019a). We do not detect any deviation from the close binary fraction of the Galaxy as a whole, placing a tight constraint on the early dynamical processing of close binaries.
  • the construction, publication, and public release of a comprehensive, value-added catalog reporting velocities and mass ratios for more than 7000 double-lined spectroscopic binaries detected in the APOGEE DR17 data release. (Kounkel et al. 2021)
  • analysis of the frequency and mass ratios of spectroscopic binaries with pre-main sequence (Fernandez et al. 2017) and M dwarf (Skinner et al. 2018) components. 
  • identification and detailed study of two eclipsing binary systems detected in the APOGEE SB2 catalog described above: pair of near-equal-mass sub-solar (M=0.6 Msun) main sequence stars (Miller et al. 2021a) and a pair of evolved stars which have exchanged mass as a result of the expansion into the red giant phase (Miller et al. 2021b). 
In addition to these research outcomes, broader impacts of this work include:
  • full funding for 4.5 years of postdoctoral training for Dr. Marina Kounkel, who has continued on to a new position at Vanderbilt University;
  • supporting research experiences for more than 20 undergraduates, and 2 masters students, at WWU. With attention to best practices in recruitment and advising, this research cohort featured near gender parity and diverse representation across socioeconomic, racial, and ethnic backgrounds.  So far, five alumni have enrolled in graduate programs, with one having already completed her PhD.
  • a multi-year observing campaign conducted by citizen scientists engaged in the Lowell Amateur Research Initiative (LARI).  Summaries of the program were presented by participants at the 34th Annual Symposium of the Society for Astronomical Sciences (Cook et al. 2015a) and the Spring 2015 meeting of the Amerian Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO; Cook et al. 2015b). Data from this campaign was contributed to the database of the American Association of Variable Star Observers (AAVSO), and has since been analyzed in several peer reviewed publications led by external scientists.
  • the PI's involvement as an advisor to student clubs that manage night-sky observing sessions for the on- and off-campus community, and those that provide community for STEM students from underrepresented groups (ie, WWU's SACNAS chapter, and the department's Physicists for Inclusion in STEM [PhIS] club).
